Description: In London, Russian agents wanted to kidnap journalist Hristo Grozev and editor-in-chief of The Insider Roman Dobrokhotov, -BBC and TelegraphA group of five Bulgarian citizens arrested in 2023 are suspected of spying for Moscow for at least three years, the BBC and Telegraph report, citing case materials. In addition to Rusev, the group also included Bizer Dzhambazov, Katrin Ivanova, Vanya Gaberova and Tihomir Ivanchev. Rusev and Dzhambazov have already pleaded guilty to espionage. The remaining defendants continue to deny the charges. Previously, journalists from The Insider and Bellingcat published high-profile investigations, including about the assassination attempt on Sergei Skripal in Salisbury. Title: In Russia, the first criminal case was opened regarding looting d...
Description: In Russia, the first criminal case was opened regarding looting during the period of hostilities against officialsHow writes -Kommersant-, defendants in a criminal case under clause -b-, part 4, article 356.1 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation - looting during an armed conflict or hostilities, associated with the conversion of someone else‚Äôs property on an especially large scale in favor of the perpetrator or other persons, became former -Deputy Chairman of the Government and former Minister of Industry and Trade of the DPR- Vladimir Rushchak, his assistant Sergei Goloshchapov, as well as Head of the departmental state unitary enterprise -Trading house -Vtormet-- Maxim Soldatov. They were accused of theft and subsequent sale of metal structures from the Azovelectrostal plant seized by Russia in 2022 in the amount of more than half a billion rubles.According to the investigation, the general director of the State Unitary Enterprise Vtormet and -other persons,- acting deliberately, by an organized group by prior conspiracy and taking advantage of the fact that military operations were ongoing on the territory of the republic, they confiscated the property of the plant -Azovelektrostal- in Russian-occupied Mariupol in the amount of at least 518 million rubles. Subsequently, it was sold through the state unitary enterprise as scrap metal, and the participants in the scheme divided the money received among themselves. Article 356.1 of the Criminal Code of the Russian Federation was introduced into the Criminal Code in the fall of 2022 after the start of mobilization in Russia. This was the first criminal case of looting brought against officials. Azovelektrostal produced railway transport, metallurgical and mining equipment. After completing the demining of the territory, it is planned to transfer it to Rostec along with other enterprises of Mariupol captured by Russia and restore their work.Before the start of the war in Donbass in 2014, Rushchak headed the National Agency for Accreditation of Ukraine, then he moved to Russia, where he became the head of the department of the Federal Accreditation Service for the Central Federal District.  After that, he was appointed -deputy head- of the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the self-proclaimed -DPR-, and in 2020 Rushchak was appointed -head of the DPR- by Denis Pushilin as head of the Ministry of Industry and Trade of the -DPR-.
